Award.AwardTitle: Random Matrix Theory and High Dimensional Statistics
Award.AbstractNarration:
High dimensional data are becoming increasingly available from a wide
range of scientific investigations, including genomics, bioinformatics,
engineering, and climate studies. Sound analysis of such datasets poses
many statistical challenges. It calls for new statistical theory and methods
as well as new technical tools. In this collaborative research project, the
investigators will first develop results and technical tools in random matrix
theory and then take a unified approach using the technical tools developed
to study several important problems in high dimensional statistics
as well as applications in signal processing, physics, and mathematics.

The statistical and scientific objectives outlined in this proposal are interdisciplinary
and will establish connections among different fields - random matrix theory, high
dimensional statistics, signal processing, physics, and mathematics. The research
will also provide technical tools as well as methodology, to researchers in other
scientific fields who collect and analyze high dimensional data. These include,
but are not limited to, genomics, biostatistics, and electrical engineering. The procedures and algorithms developed in this project will be implemented and softwares developed will be made freely and publicly available on the web as open source
code along with the associated research reports so as to facilitate the dissemination of knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tony Cai has been supported by DMS-1208982 “Random Matrix Theory and High Dimensional Statistics” ($254,944) from 9/1/12 to 8/31/16. Over these 4 years, the PI  has been working on some of the fundamental problems concerning the theoretical and methodological aspects of big data.  He led a research group of Ph.D. students, postdocs, and collaborators on developing a comprehensive theory and methodologies for high-dimensional statistics and applications in genomics and engineering. Much progress has been made towards the goals outlined in this proposal.

Major Outcomes and Activities:

1. Published over 50 journal papers during the period, including more than 30 papers in leading statistics/engineering journals such as the Annals of Statistics, Journal of the American Statistical Association, Journal of the Royal Statistical Society (Series B), Biometrika, and IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, and IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing. The newly proposed procedures were implemented in R and/or Matlab. All the papers and software were made freely available on his website.
2. Developed an optimality theory for estimation of large covariance and precision matrices and proposed novel methods for statistical inference on high-dimensional covariance structures; Developed adaptive procedures and established optimal rates for sparse PCA; Established sharp RIP conditions for compressed sensing and low-rank matrix recovery;  Addressed a range of applications in medical research, including copy number variation analysis and identifying gene regulatory networks with gene expression data. 
3. Presented 49 colloquium talks, 38 invited talks and 21 plenary/distinguished lectures at scientific conferences, including   Hermann Otto Hirschfeld Lectures at Humboldt-Universitat zu Berlin,  Plenary talk at the 7th Information Theory and Applications Conference, Plenary Lecture at the International Conference on Robust Statistics, and Keynote Lecture at the Symposium on Frontiers of Statistics and Data Science.
4. Co-organized 7 international conferences on topics directly related to research supported by the NSF grants: “NSF Workshop for High-Dimensional Data: Theory, Methodology and Applications" at Yale in June 2012;  Oberwolfach workshop “Frontiers in Nonparametric Statistics" in Germany in March 2012;  “International Conference on Frontiers of Statistics" in Beijing in June 2013; “Joint Meeting of the IMS and Australian Statistical Conference" in Sydney in July 2014; “International Conference on Data Science" in Dali, China, in July 2016;  “2016 International Conference on Data Science" in Shanghai in December 2016; and the 2017 IMS Annual Meeting in Baltimore in August 2017.

Intellectual Merit: 

Under the support of this NSF grant, Tony Cai developed optimality theories and novel methods  for estimation of large covariance/precision matrices, detection of structured signals, sparse PCA, and low-rank matrix recovery.  He also developed inference procedures for network analysis, high-dimensional linear regression, and nonparametric regression.  These results advanced the theoretical understanding and methodological development for high-dimensional statistics and analysis of Big Data. In addition, he addressed a range of applications in medical research, including copy number variation analysis and identifying gene regulatory networks with gene expression data. 

Broader Impacts:  

The results developed by Tony Cai  have a great impact in the broad scientific community. They provide theory, methodology, applications, as well as technical tools to researchers in other scientific fields who collect and analyze high-dimensional data sets. These fields include astronomy, biology, chemistry, bioinformatics, as well as various clinical research areas in general. In the last four years, Tony Cai trained (and is training) 8 postdocs and 11 Ph.D. students, including 3 female postdocs and 1 female student, all of whom have taken up faculty positions at research universities. %including UC Davis, UIUC, UNC Chapel Hill, NCSU, UW Madison. To disseminate the newly obtained results, he taught advanced topics courses on high dimensional statistical inference and nonparametric inference to Ph.D. students and postdocs at Penn. He also organized a special seminar series dedicated to high dimensional data analysis and gave public lectures at other institutions. The seminar series was well attended by the faculty and graduate students at Penn. All the papers and implementations of the procedures in R/Matlab were available online.
